Literature Review: L-Serine, a non-essential amino acid, plays a crucial role in various metabolic processes and has garnered significant attention in recent years due to its implications in health and disease. This literature review aims to explore the sources and sinks of serine in nutrition, health, and disease contexts, highlighting its importance in cellular metabolism and potential therapeutic applications.Serine biosynthesis and metabolism are intricately linked to multiple metabolic pathways. The primary source of serine in the body is through de novo synthesis, which occurs via the phosphorylated pathway in most tissues (Locasale et al., 2011). This pathway involves the conversion of 3-phosphoglycerate, an intermediate of glycolysis, to serine through a series of enzymatic reactions. Additionally, serine can be derived from glycine through the reversible action of serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which is part of the folate-mediated one-carbon metabolism (Ducker and Rabinowitz, 2017).The liver and kidneys play essential roles in serine homeostasis. The liver is a major site of serine synthesis and degradation, while the kidneys contribute to serine reabsorption and de novo synthesis (Kalhan and Hanson, 2012). Interestingly, the brain has been shown to produce serine locally, which is crucial for proper neuronal function and development (Ehmsen et al., 2013).Serine metabolism is tightly regulated and interconnected with various metabolic pathways. It serves as a precursor for the synthesis of glycine, cysteine, and phospholipids, and contributes to the generation of one-carbon units for methylation reactions and nucleotide synthesis (Yang and Vousden, 2016). Furthermore, serine is involved in the biosynthesis of sphingolipids and plays a role in redox homeostasis through its conversion to glycine and subsequent synthesis of glutathione (Amelio et al., 2014).Dysregulation of serine metabolism has been implicated in various pathological conditions. Genetic disorders affecting serine biosynthesis, such as 3-phosphoglycerate dehydrogenase deficiency, can lead to severe neurological manifestations, highlighting the importance of serine in brain function (van der Crabben et al., 2013). Moreover, altered serine metabolism has been observed in neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease, suggesting a potential role in disease progression (Esposito et al., 2013).In the context of cancer, serine metabolism has emerged as a critical factor in tumor growth and progression. Many cancer cells exhibit upregulated serine biosynthesis pathways, which contribute to their proliferative capacity and survival (Mattaini et al., 2016). This metabolic reprogramming has led to the exploration of serine pathway inhibitors as potential therapeutic targets in cancer treatment (Pacold et al., 2016).Recent studies have also highlighted the importance of serine in diabetes and its complications. Diabetic neuropathy, a common complication of diabetes, has been associated with impaired serine metabolism. Gao et al. (2019) demonstrated that dietary serine supplementation could alleviate diabetic sensory neuropathy in animal models, suggesting a potential therapeutic approach for this condition.The role of serine in muscle health and aging has gained attention in recent years. Aging is associated with a decline in muscle mass and function, and alterations in serine metabolism may contribute to this process. Koivisto et al. (2016) reported that serine levels decrease with age in human skeletal muscle and that serine supplementation improved muscle regeneration in aged mice.Given the diverse roles of serine in health and disease, there is growing interest in developing diagnostic tools to assess serine homeostasis. The concept of a serine tolerance test, as mentioned in the abstract, could provide valuable insights into an individual's serine metabolism and potentially identify those at risk for neuropathy or other serine-related disorders (Mardinoglu et al., 2017).In conclusion, serine occupies a central position in cellular metabolism, linking various metabolic pathways and contributing to essential biological processes. The intricate balance of serine sources and sinks plays a crucial role in maintaining health, and dysregulation of serine metabolism is implicated in numerous pathological conditions. Further research into serine metabolism and its modulation through dietary interventions or pharmacological approaches may lead to novel therapeutic strategies for a range of diseases, including neurological disorders, cancer, and age-related conditions.
